    Farnesyl Pyrophosphate Synthase as a Target for Drug Development: Discovery of Natural-Product-Derived Inhibitors and Their Activity in Pancreatic Cancer Cells

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Human farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (Homo sapiens FPPS, HsFPPS) is a target for treating bone resorption diseases and some cancers. HsFPPS is potently inhibited by bisphosphonates, but due to poor cell penetration and distribution in soft tissue, there is currently interest in the development of non-bisphosphonate inhibitors as cancer therapeutics. Here, we report the discovery and development of HsFPPS inhibitors based on the phenolic diterpene carnosic acid (CA), an antimicrobial found in rosemary and sage, which showed better cellular anticancer activities than the bisphosphonate drug zoledronate in pancreatic cancer cell lines, as well as an HsFPPS-dependent mechanism of action. Hit-to-lead optimization of CA improved HsFPPS inhibition by >100-fold. A slow dissociation inhibition pattern and a noncompetitive allosteric binding mode were found, and cellular mechanism-of-action studies showed that these inhibitors inhibit tumor cell growth primarily by inhibiting HsFPPS, leading to downregulation of Ras prenylation and cell apoptosis. The discovery of this series of compounds together with proof-of-mechanism in pancreatic cancer cells may pave the way for targeting HsFPPS in soft tissue cancers using natural-product-derived inhibitors.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Terpenoids, also known as isoprenoids, constitute the largest class of natural products.(1) Isoprenoids are produced by all organisms, and many isoprenoid biosynthesis enzymes are drug targets or potential drug targets. For example, in humans, the cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor targets an âupstreamâ enzyme, hydroxymethylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase; the antiosteoporosis drug zoledronate targets farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase, inhibiting protein prenylation and cell signaling; while the antifungal drug terbinafine targets squalene epoxidase, even further downstream in isoprenoid biosynthesis, inhibiting ergosterol biosynthesis in fungi. In addition to these well-known targets and mechanisms of action, we recently showed that isoprenoid biosynthesis is a target for vaccine adjuvant discovery,(2) expanding the potential of this ancient pathway as a drug target.
    Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase is the âgatekeeper enzyme(3)â for mammalian isoprenoid biosynthesis and catalyzes the condensation of dimethylallyl pyrophosphate (1, DMAPP) and isopentenyl pyrophosphate (2, IPP), forming geranyl pyrophosphate (3, GPP) and then farnesyl pyrophosphate (4, FPP) (Figure 1). Further condensation of FPP with IPP is catalyzed by geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate synthase (GGPPS) and yields geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (5, GGPP), Figure 1. Both FPP and GGPP are used in protein prenylation, and FPP can be converted into many downstream products including cholesterol, CoQ10, and the dolichols.(4)
    Protein prenylation involves the post-translational modification of proteins such as Ras, Rac, Rab, and Rho and these prenylated proteins are essential for protein localization to cell membranes,(5) required for cell signaling and proliferation.(6) Inhibition of human FPPS (Homo sapiens FPPS, HsFPPS) can, therefore, downregulate the activity of mutated Ras, one of the most frequent oncogenic mutations (â¼33% of human cancers).(7â9) In addition, inhibition of HsFPPS causes accumulation of the substrates IPP and DMAPP. These molecules are known as phosphoantigens and they have the interesting property that they can induce activation of Î³Î´ T cells.(10â12) Thus, HsFPPS inhibition has also been shown to lead to immune killing of some cancer cells.(13,14) It has also been shown that elevated HsFPPS expression is found in Alzheimerâs disease brain samples(15) and is believed to contribute to neuronal dysfunction,(16) so HsFPPS inhibitors may additionally have potential in treating neurodegenerative diseases.(3)
    Since bisphosphonates such as zoledronate (Figure 2a, 6) inhibit HsFPPS and have been reported to have utility in treating breast cancer and multiple myeloma,(17â24) efforts have been made to make improved inhibitors since the bisphosphonates in current use have poor membrane permeability, poor soft tissue distribution, and potent bone affinity, removing them from the circulatory system. One approach to alleviate these drawbacks has been to produce lipophilic bisphosphonates such as 7,(25) since lipophilic bisphosphonates are expected to have much better cell penetration, as well as weak bone affinity. A second approach has been to develop completely different HsFPPS inhibitors, compounds lacking the polar bisphosphonate moiety. This approach was first developed by Jahnke and co-workers at Novartis(26) (e.g., with 8) and since this work, numerous non-bisphosphonateHsFPPS inhibitors have been reported.(27â32) For example, the (C20) diterpenoid arenarone (9)(29) inhibits HsFPPS as does the bisamidine BPH-1358 (10),(30) as well as the monophosphonate 11.(32) Some of these compounds showed potent in vitro activities against HsFPPS, but few had good cellular (or animal) HsFPPS-dependent anticancer activities,(26â30) so there is still a need for new scaffold, non-bisphosphonate HsFPPS inhibitors.
    What is of interest about 1â4 and 6â11 is that they display a very broad variety of binding modes to HsFPPS, a highly Î±-helical protein (Figure S1a), as shown in Figures 2bâh and S1aâc. Ligand binding for 2, 4, and 6â11 is illustrated in Figures 2b and S1b,c using a cartoon representation for the protein to facilitate a good comparison between the different binding sites, while the protein is shown as a surface in Figure 2câh in order to show ligand exposure. Figure S1c is the stereoview of Figure 2b. The two main catalytic sites in HsFPPS are the S1 site, which binds the allylic substrates DMAPP (1) or GPP (3) and 3 Mg2+, and the S2 site, which binds the homoallylic substrate IPP (2). The bisphosphonate zoledronate (6) also binds to the S1 site with 3 Mg2+ with IPP binding to S2, Figure S1b (PDB code 2F8Z). Likewise, the lipophilic bisphosphonate 7 binds to the S1 site with 3 Mg2+, Figure 2b (in red, PDB code 4N1Z), but the dicarboxylate 8 binds to an allosteric site S3 (magenta, PDB code 3N6K) and has a partial overlap with the S2 site, Figure 2b. Arenarone binds to another hydrophobic site, Figure 2b (slate, PDB code 4P0W) that is close to S2. The large bisamidine 10 has three rings that are located close to the S2 and S3 sites (Figure 2b, green, PDB code 4RXA), while the other half of the molecule is located in another pocket called the S4 site.(30) FPP itself is also known to act as an HsFPPS allosteric inhibitor(33) in which one phosphate group overlays an IPP phosphate position while the farnesyl side chain occupies a hydrophobic pocket (Figure 2g, wheat, PDB code 5JA0), the distal part of the farnesyl side chain occupying the same S4 site as seen with the bisamidine 10. In structures that contain 3 Mg2+, the ligands are buried in the interior of the protein (Figure 2c,e), but in the absence of Mg2+, the structures are more open and ligands are more visible (Figure 2d,f,g,h). In more recent work,(32) novel phosphate-containing allosteric inhibitors have been reported with 11 being found to bind close to sites 2 and 3 (yellow, PDB code 5JV2), Figure 2b, but surprisingly, the phosphate group is not buried in the interior of the protein, Figure 2h. What is common, then, about most HsFPPS-inhibitor structures is that the known allosteric inhibitors occupy relatively exposed surface sites in the S2, S3 and S4 regions, while bisphosphonates bind to S1 and lead (especially in the presence of IPP) to pocket closure.
    Here, we report the identification and development of novel scaffold, carnosic acid (Figure 3) and carnosol-based HsFPPS inhibitors with nanomolar potency, as well as a structureâactivity relationship (SAR) exploration of the series. We investigated their binding to HsFPPS by NMR (water-ligand observed via gradient spectroscopy, WaterLOGSY; saturation-difference NMR, STD NMR) and surface plasmon resonance (SPR), cell growth inhibition activity utilizing PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2 cell lines, and geranylgeraniol and farnesol cell growth inhibitionârescue experiments. This work expands the toolbox of non-bisphosphonateHsFPPS inhibitors to lipophilic, natural-product-derived compounds and is a systematic proof-of-mechanism study in pancreatic cancer cells suggesting that targeting HsFPPS by carnosic acid-derived inhibitors may be a potential route to treating certain soft tissue cancers.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Hit Compound Discovery

    In earlier work we found that the diterpenoids taxodone (12), taxodione (13), and arenarone (9) were HsFPPS inhibitors(29) and that taxodione and arenarone bound to a hydrophobic pocket in HsFPPS with one ring occupying the position of the IPP, S2 site. These results were of interest since these diterpenoids are structurally similar to carnosic acid and carnosol (Figure 3), compounds that are abundant in rosemary and sage extracts, plants that form part of the Mediterranean diet that has been associated with decreased cardiovascular and diabetes risk.(34) Rosemary and sage extracts abundant in carnosic acid and carnosol have also been reported to have anticancer,(35) antimicrobial,(36) and cholesterol-lowing effects,(37â39) but little is known about their molecular targets, in cells.(34,40) Given the structural similarities between carnosic acid, carnosol, taxodione, and arenarone, we hypothesized that carnosic acid and carnosol might function, at least in part, by inhibiting HsFPPS. We thus tested their activities in a PPi (inorganic pyrophosphate) release assay(27,29,41,42) finding that both carnosic acid and carnosol inhibited HsFPPS with IC50 values of 20.0 Î¼M and 13.3 Î¼M, respectively. Considering its commercial availability, we chose carnosic acid as our hit compound to develop novel non-bisphosphonate HsFPPS inhibitors.

    Inhibitor Design and Synthesis Strategy

    Having confirmed carnosic acidâs (hereinafter referred to as CA) activity toward HsFPPS, we synthesized three major types of inhibitor (Figure 4) based on the CAâs structure: (1) derivatives exploring the carboxyl group space (C4a); (2) derivatives with modification at the benzyl position (C9); (3) the oxidation state of the series 1 compounds. The carboxyl group of CA is readily modified with various amines to produce amides or heterocyclic compounds, based on condensation reactions, while esterification seemed less desirable since esters might hydrolyze in cells. The benzyl position of CA (C9) can be easily oxidized, after which various substituents can be introduced via Michael addition.(43) Then, Michael adducts can be further oxidized leading to quinones. The benzyl position and the para-phenol group together give CA relatively high reactivity, leading to series 3. We designed these three types of derivatives mainly because they can be easily obtained through routine reactions, thus enabling us to quickly extend our SAR exploration despite their different modification sites (e.g., C4a and C9) compared with the previously reported taxod(i)one (C10). We also found that, due to CAâs spatial structure and high reactivity of the benzyl position and phenol groups, many other derivatives including bridged compounds could be obtained, as discussed in detail below.

    Chemistry

    A series of CA derivatives were synthesized according to the routes depicted in Schemes 1â4. Because of the reactivity of CA, we first used methylation with trimethylsilyldiazomethane (TMSCHN2) leading to compound CA1 in good yield (79%). Further oxidation using 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanobenzoquinone (DDQ) or Ag2O provided CA2 in 67% yield, which served as a Michael addition receptor for the next modifications at position C9. Acetylation of the catechol hydroxyls of CA provided CA3 in a high yield (97%). We introduced various substituents at C4a of CA3 via amide condensation, leading to CA4a-l. The condensation reactions involved two steps: oxalyl chloride treatment of CA3 in the presence of a catalytic amount DMF yielded the corresponding acyl chloride which was then reacted with various of amines in the next step. Yields ranged from about 30% to 80%. Deprotections of CA4a-l were carried out using p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA) or LiAlH4, as appropriate, leading to CA5a-l. Oxidation at the C9 position of CA4d-l was only achieved with CA4d. Reactions of CA4e-l with CrO3 were unsuccessful, due presumably to the instability of these compounds under drastic oxidation conditions. Compound CA7 was prepared from CA6 via LiAlH4 reduction in nearly quantitative yield. Compound CA4l was synthesized from CA4h and N-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-l-alanine using hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyluronium (HATU) condensation, in 68% yield.
    Various modifications of the phenolic hydroxyl (C9 and C10) positions of CA1 were carried out leading to CA8aâc, CA10, CA11a,b, and CA12â14 (Scheme 2). Different protecting groups including tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS), benzyl (Bn), and acetyl (Ac) on the phenolic hydroxyls of CA1 were used providing CA8aâc. Compounds CA8a,b were all monosubstitution products because of TBS or Bnâs steric hindrance. To avoid side reactions of the phenolic hydroxyls in the following steps, we chose the dual-acetyl protection product CA8c as our starting point. CA9 was prepared by CrO3 oxidation in a 70% yield. CA14 was obtained in high yield (â¼80%) by the deprotection of CA9, followed by DDQ oxidation of CA10. Carbonyl Î±-halogenation of CA9 gave the target compounds CA11a,b. Further deprotection of CA11a afforded an unexpected product, CA12, presumably because the intramolecular nucleophilic substitution of chloride can occur after methyl ester hydrolysis, under acid conditions. Following DDQ oxidation of CA12, the corresponding quinone CA13 was obtained in quantitative yield.
    Next, on the basis of the strong intramolecular nucleophilicity mentioned above, we constructed several additional bridged compounds: CA19â22 (Scheme 3). CA22 was obtained by a two-step DDQ oxidation procedure or a single step oxidation using 2 equiv of DDQ. CA20 was obtained in a similar manner except that there was an additional (LiAlH4) reduction of the methyl ester before DDQ oxidation. On the basis of the observations that DDQ oxidation of CA1 yielded CA2, it appears that formation of CA19 and CA21 involves dehydrogenation of the phenolic hydroxyl at C6 and the methylene at C9, Figure S2, leading to a highly reactive intermediate. This intermediate would be a typical Michael addition receptor which could then react with its own Michael addition donor (carbonyl or hydroxyl) to form the corresponding bridged compounds. In addition, CA17 was readily prepared via an intramolecular DCC condensation. To further explore substituent effects at the C9 position, we utilized CA2 as a Michael addition receptor to install various substituents at C9, leading to CA15aâf. Subsequent oxidation of CA15c, CA15e, and CA15f by DDQ yielded CA16aâc, respectively.
    Scheme 4 shows the syntheses of CA25aâg, CA27aâe, and CA28aâd. CA4iâk were obtained as described above and as shown in Scheme 1 (here, for condition a1). Compounds CA23aâc were prepared by reaction of CA4h with the corresponding carboxyl (R5COOH) by using HATU. CA4iâj were treated directly with POCl3, and intramolecular ring closing and deprotection were accomplished in one step, leading to CA25a,b. Since the workup of the POCl3 reaction was not particularly convenient, we finally chose another more moderate ring-closing strategy, utilizing p-toluenesulfonyl chloride (p-TsCl). CA24câf were formed readily from CA23a,b, CA4k, and CA23c using this approach. Subsequent acetyl deprotection by p-TSA or LiAlH4 gave the corresponding CA25c,d and CA25f,g. Interestingly, lengthy (12 h) LiAlH4 reduction of CA24d yielded another side-product, CA25e. Oxidation of CA24a and CA24dâe gave CA26aâd smoothly. CA26c was also the side product of CrO3 oxidation when CA24d was reacted for 12 h. It appears that CA24d may first undergo benzyl oxidation, followed by oxidation of the CâN bond to yield an imine intermediate which is readily hydrolyzed to the corresponding ketone (CA26c) under acid conditions. CA28aâd were afforded by acetyl deprotection of CA26aâd and subsequent DDQ oxidation of CA27aâd.

    StructureâActivity Relationships for HsFPPS Inhibition

    As noted above, there are three major, readily modifiable sites in CA, so we next discuss how modifications at these sites affect HsFPPS inhibition. We first investigated carboxyl group modifications, obtaining CA1 from CA by methylation. Perhaps surprisingly, CA1 showed greatly enhanced (>20-fold) inhibition activity as compared to CA itself (IC50 = 20 Î¼M) with an IC50 = 865 nM, Table 1. Because CA1 possesses a catechol group, which is an alerting PAINS (pan-assay interference compounds) substructure,(44) we confirmed its physical binding to HsFPPS by SPR and PAINS exclusion experiments, as will be discussed below. Also of interest, the activity of CA2 (IC50 = 833 nM) was very similar to that of CA1. These results were encouraging and suggested that removing a likely carboxylate charge might facilitate binding to the hydrophobic channel seen in HsFPPS structures and that both reduced and oxidized species can bind, but of course, esters may be undesirable because they often hydrolyze in cells. We thus next explored amides rather than esters, despite the potent activity of CA1 and CA2.
    Table 1. IC50 of Compounds on HsFPPS and HsGGPPS Activitya
    a

    ND, not determined.

    We next synthesized the series of amides CA5aâl to further explore whether the carboxyl group might be masked as well as extended, to improve hydrophobic interactions (and cell penetration) but without steric clashes with HsFPPS. As can be seen in Table 1, methyl (CA5a) and benzyl (CA5c) substitutions increased the IC50 values from those seen with CA1 (and CA2) by 7.4-fold and 3.3-fold, respectively, but addition of a cycloheptyl group (compound CA5b) decreased activity far more dramatically (by >50-fold). Since the cycloheptyl and benzyl groups have the same number of carbons and similar sizes, aromatic groups are clearly preferred, and since the results described above indicated that neutral (methyl ester) groups were preferred over (likely anionic) carboxylates, we next investigated other neutral (as well as basic) species, including several with aromatic groups.
    We first produced compound CA5d, which contains a dimethylaminoethyl terminal group. Its activity was improved by 16.7-fold versus CA1 to 1.2 Î¼M. However, CA5e, which instead of a dimethylaminoethyl group contains a hydroxyethyl side-chain, had slightly increased activity compared to CA5d, similar to that of CA1. The imidazole (CA5f) and pyridine (CA5g) species had improved activity over CA but less so than with CA1 or CA 5d/e, possibly due to the length of their carbon linker groups. However, the short chain hydrazide species CA5h had very poor activity (IC50 = 35 Î¼M). Masking the hydrazide amino group with small (acetyl, formyl) substituents (CA5i and CA5j) resulted in good activity with CA5i having IC50 = 1.5 Î¼M. Moreover, with more hydrophobic substituents (CA5k and CA5l), there was even better activity (in the 500â800 nM range, Table 1). Taken together, these results indicate that the presence of the carboxyl/carboxylate group in CA is undesirable for HsFPPS inhibition, but conversion to amide and substituted amides can result in large increases in activity, the best inhibitors having relatively large, neutral, hydrophobic groups (CA5k, clogP and clogD7.4 = 6.37, 6.36; CA5l, clogP and clogD7.4 = 4.96, 1.62). The IC50 values for these compounds in these HsFPPS assays were in the 500â800 nM range, to be compared with â¼100â200 nM for 6 (zoledronate, clogP and clogD7.4 = â3.85, â7.39).
    Next, we explored the effects of modifications of the phenol groups in CA. Monoprotection or dual-protection as in CA8aâc and CA11a,b all greatly decreased activity or eliminated it, in most cases independent of the protecting group used. Halogenation at position C10 of CA9 did not contribute to any activity increase in compounds CA11a,b. These results indicate that the phenol groups are essential for activity against HsFPPS. Oxidation at position C9 of CA1 led to compounds CA10 and CA12, which both retain the catechol moiety but have greatly reduced activity (CA10 IC50 = 41.2 Î¼M, CA12 IC50 > 100 Î¼M). However, the catechol oxidation products CA13 and CA14 in which the C9 carbonyl is also present both showed potent HsFPPS inhibition. The IC50 values were 0.389 Î¼M for CA13 and 0.523 Î¼M for CA14, approaching that of 6, due perhaps to covalent inhibition, as discussed below. We also performed selectivity studies for HsFPPS versus HsGGPPS inhibition, and Table 1 shows that all compounds with <1 Î¼M IC50 toward HsFPPS were selective HsFPPS inhibitors. The selectivity index ranged from â¼20 to >200.
    Next, we investigated a series of CA analogs, CA15aâf, modified at the C9 position using S or O linker atoms. Large substituents had little effect or reduced activity, but methyl (CA15e) and hydroxyethyl (CA15c) substituents had good activity with IC50 of â¼1 Î¼M, Table 2. We then turned to an exploration of the effects of oxidation of three of these compounds, CA15c, CA15e, and CA15f, to determine if utilizing quinone groups enhanced activity. DDQ oxidation led to compounds CA16aâc with CA16b (from CA15e, the methoxy analog) having potent activity with IC50 â¼ 200 nM, Table 2, almost 100-fold more active than CA and comparable to 6. Interestingly, the presence of the quinone structures in CA16a and CA16c did not greatly improve their activities, unlike the situation with CA13 and CA14. The reason for this is not known.
    Table 2. IC50 of Compounds on HsFPPS and HsGGPPS Activitya
    a

    ND, not determined.

    b

    Note that the R/S configuration shown is the overall moleculeâs stereochemistry, not the fragmentâs.

    As noted above in the synthesis section, we discovered several bridged or polycyclic compounds during our initial work so we next synthesized and tested a series of such analogs of CA, compounds CA17, 19â22. CA17 has the carboxyl group esterified with a phenol OH-group to make a cyclic ester and had an IC50 of 10.6 Î¼M, in accord with our previous finding that no phenol group substitution improved activity. A 2.6-fold activity increase was achieved with CA18 in which the carbonyl group is reduced. This seems a surprisingly small effect since the charge would be masked, but both CA19 and CA21 also showed only minor activity improvements compared with CA so it appears that charge-masking by a hydrophobic species is preferable in the phenol series. However, oxidation of CA19 and CA21 to CA20 and CA22 resulted in large (â¼30-fold) increases in activity with IC50 values of 0.596 Î¼M and 0.473 Î¼M, respectively, basically as seen with CA13 and CA14.
    The results described above indicate that hydrophobic groups can be well tolerated at the C4a position of CA, while substitutions at C9 or phenol group modifications (other than oxidations) are undesirable. We thus next synthesized and tested compounds CA25aâg and some of their corresponding oxidation products, CA28aâd. Since we found that CA5iâl all showed excellent activities toward HsFPPS, we chose this hydrazide-based series to develop derivatives. Ring closure of CA23 led to the oxadiazole CA24, and as can be seen in Table 2, modifications of the 1,3,4-oxadiazole side chains in some cases increased their activity. CA25a, with a 2-methyl-1,3,4-oxadiazole substituent, inhibited HsFPPS with an IC50 of 2.20 Î¼M, but CA25b, with a 2-amino-1,3,4-oxadiazole substituent, resulted in an IC50 of 0.859 Î¼M. CA25c, with a terminal N,N-dimethylmethyleneamine substituent, did not show any potency improvement, having IC50 = 1.00 Î¼M, similar to that of CA25d (IC50 = 0.644 Î¼M), while CA25e had more potent (IC50 = 0.194 Î¼M) activity, the same as the control compound zoledronate (6, IC50 = 0.1â0.2 Î¼M). Compared to compounds CA25a and CA25b, the substituents in CA25d and CA25e were quite large but they could still be tolerated and the compounds exhibited potent activity. The addition of phenyl substituents with compounds CA25f and CA25g resulted in greatly decreased activity, perhaps due to steric clashes with the protein. Oxidation at position C9 yielded CA27aâe and with the exception of CA27b, each compound lost its inhibition activity toward HsFPPS. On the other hand, CA28aâc, the (quinone) oxidation products of CA27aâc all had IC50 values of â¼300 nM. The bromophenyl was again only moderately active, Table 2. Finally, we tested most compounds against HsGGPPS, Table 2. Compounds with IC50 < 1 Î¼M were all selective HsFPPS inhibitors with selectivity indexes in the â¼30â200 range.
    Finally, we briefly summarize these SAR results, as shown in Figure 5. The catechol series (Figure 5a) encompass a wide range of structures with the R group being an ester, an amide (from methylamine, benzylamine, hydroxyethylamine, an amine of a terminal basic aryl group, a hydrazide), or a 1,3,4-oxadiazole and its derivatives. In general, larger hydrophobic groups that mask the carboxyl charge increased activity. Typical examples are CA5k and CA5l. 1,3,4-Oxadiazoles were generally better than amides, although large oxadiazole substituents decreased activity, as with CA25f and CA25g. As for the phenolic hydroxyl moiety, OH modifications blocked activity. Modifications at C9 (shown as a red X) reduced activity, although the methoxy substitution was an exception. As for quinone series, Figure 5b, they generally had good activity with 8 of the 11 compounds having IC50 values of â¼500 nM. Activity was only moderate when X was an ethoxy group or a mercaptoethyl group (8.60 Î¼M and 22.7 Î¼M). Incorporation of a large aromatic group (such as p-bromophenyl) to the oxadiazole again reduced activity (CA28d, 13.7 Î¼M). The questions then arise as to whether the compounds synthesized are PAINS compounds: Is there independent evidence that they bind to HsFPPS? Are any active in cells, and if they are, is there evidence that HsFPPS and prenylation are being targeted?

    PAINS Property Evaluation

    As noted above, the compounds in this study possess alerting PAINS substructures:(44,45) catechols and quinones. Such compounds might interfere with assays in a variety of ways including via redox reactions/colorimetric interference effects, aggregation, binding to coupling enzymes, and metal chelation. We thus carried out a series of experiments aimed at studying ligand binding and protein inhibition in more detail. First, we directly measured product formation/inhibition using a [14C]-IPP radioactive assay. Second, we investigated the effects of Triton X-100 on activity/inhibition. Third, we used NMR (water-ligand observed via gradient spectroscopy, WaterLOGSY) to observe ligand binding. Fourth, we used surface plasmon resonance (SPR) to directly measure ligand binding. Plus, as discussed in the next section, we carried out conventional enzyme inhibition kinetics experiments to help determine inhibition mechanisms, as well as LCâMS to probe potential covalent adduct formation.
    We first used a [14C]-IPP radioactivity assay(46) to measure the inhibition of product formation. By using isotopically labeled IPP as the substrate, we directly detect the amount of product formed after inhibition, avoiding possible interference in a coupling assay. We chose two representative compounds, CA20 and CA28a, as our test compounds with zoledronate (6) as the positive control. As can be seen in Table 3, CA20 and CA28a both showed inhibition of HsFPPS in this [14C]-IPP radioactivity assay. The amounts of enzyme and substrate differ in the PPi and radioactive assays, as do the methods (kinetics versus end-point), so there is a systematic difference between the IC50 values obtained (in the 1.7â4.5Ã range), but this is not unexpected and is seen in other related work.(47)
    Table 3. Inhibition Data of Some Compounds on HsFPPS Activity with Different Assays
    compdPPi release assay (Î¼M) IC50Â Â±Â SD, nÂ =Â 4[14C]-IPP assay (Î¼M) IC50Â Â±Â SD, nÂ =Â 3([14C]-IPPÂ IC50)/(PPiÂ IC50)
    60.1Â Â±Â 0.00340.17Â Â±Â NDa1.7
    CA200.596Â Â±Â 0.0792.7Â Â±Â 0.0404.5
    CA28a0.335Â Â±Â 0.0111.3Â Â±Â 0.0803.9
    a

    ND, not determined.

    Next, since catechols and quinones can produce H2O2 during their redox cycling,(48â50) we added catalase in our assay in order to avoid possible reducing factors(49) that might interfere with the results. CA28a and CA28b had nearly the same inhibition potency with or without catalase (Table S1). However, this in vitro experiment cannot exclude the possible influence of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which may be generated intracellularly by these compounds. Catechols can also chelate Mg2+ (which is essential for HsFPPS catalysis), so we added 2 mM Mg2+, and since the highest concentration of our compounds was no more than 100 Î¼M, there would be no significant effect of catechol-metal binding.
    Aggregation is another possible effect of PAINS compounds, but aggregation can be disrupted by adding nonionic detergents such as Triton X-100 or Tween-80.(48) Online tools such as Aggregator Advisor(51) (http://advisor.bkslab.org/search/) can also help identify such molecules, so we first screened most compounds in silico on this site but found no alerting structures. We then assayed most compounds with IC50 < 1 Î¼M again but this time in the presence of 0.01% Triton X-100, and as can be seen in Table 4, they all had very similar activity to that obtained in the absence of Triton X-100, making aggregation unlikely.
    Table 4. IC50 of Some Compounds on HsFPPS Activity with 0.01% Triton X-100 in Assay
    compdIC50 in assay without 0.01% Triton X-100 (Î¼M), IC50Â Â±Â SD, nÂ =Â 4IC50 in assay with 0.01% Triton X-100 (Î¼M), IC50Â Â±Â SD, nÂ =Â 4
    60.10â0.200.14â0.30
    CA10.87Â Â±Â 0.0450.47Â Â±Â 0.14
    CA20.83Â Â±Â 0.0650.81Â Â±Â 0.19
    CA5e0.91Â Â±Â 0.0440.65Â Â±Â 0.058
    CA5k0.80Â Â±Â 0.111.52Â Â±Â 0.22
    CA130.39Â Â±Â 0.0140.40Â Â±Â 0.28
    CA140.52Â Â±Â 0.0530.43Â Â±Â 0.026
    CA200.60Â Â±Â 0.0790.23Â Â±Â 0.033
    CA25b0.86Â Â±Â 0.220.39Â Â±Â 0.0063
    CA25c1.00Â Â±Â 0.140.70Â Â±Â 0.17
    CA25e0.19Â Â±Â 0.00660.62Â Â±Â 0.032
    CA28a0.34Â Â±Â 0.0110.73Â Â±Â 0.072
    CA28b0.25Â Â±Â 0.0170.23Â Â±Â 0.0086
    CA28c0.29Â Â±Â 0.0270.31Â Â±Â 0.0070
    Next, we investigated ligand binding to HsFPPS using WaterLOGSY experiments (Figure 6) and SPR (Figure 7). First, we used WaterLOGSY(26,52) to verify binding of CA28a to HsFPPS. In the absence of HsFPPS, the WaterLOGSY NMR spectrum of CA28a (200 Î¼M) in Tris buffer alone shows only very weak signals (Figure 6a, in red). However, in the presence of HsFPPS (10 Î¼M) and again in Tris buffer (and in the absence of Mg2+), there are now five sharp peaks (Figure 6a, in blue). These resonances arise from CA28a and exhibit a negative nuclear Overhauser enhancement (by convention, shown as upright peaks in this experiment) due to protein binding and can be assigned as follows (see numbering system used in Figure 6b): Î´ = 7.51 ppm, H14; Î´ = 2.31 ppm, Me on the oxadiazole ring; Î´ â¼ 1.04 ppm, isopropyl methyl groups H16 and H17; Î´ = 0.85 ppm, H18; and Î´ = 0.33 ppm, H19. The shifts are essentially the same as seen in CDCl3 except for the oxadiazole methyl which is shifted by â¼0.2 ppm due to a solvent effect. An interesting observation is that there is a large (â¼0.5 ppm) shielding of one of the methyl groups attached to C4 in CA28a (in this experiment and in organic solvent), but this is not unexpected since as shown in Figure 6c, the protons on C19 are expected to undergo a significant upfield ring current shift (a shielding) due to their interaction with the oxadiazole ring, if it adopts the conformation deduced in the computational experiments discussed below. The shift is not seen in compounds that lack the ring. The WaterLOGSY experiments thus confirm that CA28a binds to HsFPPS. Similar experiments were also performed on CA5d, and at least 2â3 peaks reversals were observed upon adding HsFPPS (Figure S3). Since CA28a and CA5d represent typical quinone and catechol series inhibitors, their qualitative results supporting physical bindings promoted us to further explore some representative derivativesâ quantitative binding affinities by SPR.
    The SPR results with CA1, CA5l, CA13, and CA28a showed that all compounds except CA5l displayed slow dissociation behavior (Figure 7). We employed a single-cycle kinetic analysis for all compounds because of the difficult regeneration steps during normal titration.(53,54) All four compounds associated with HsFPPS with a similar association rate constant (kon) of about (2â5) Ã 102 Mâ1 sâ1. Since these association rate constants are of the same order of magnitude, the binding constants mainly depend on the dissociation rate constant (koff). For example, the high binding affinities of CA13 (KD = 448 nM) and CA28a (KD = 61.6 nM) correlate with their slow dissociation rates of 1.23 Ã 10â4 sâ1 (CA13) and 3.18 Ã 1 0â5 sâ1 (CA28a). These results show that most of these compounds will reside on the protein for a long time after binding, with the residence time Ï = 1/ koff for CA28a meaning that it could remain bound for â¼9 h. Long Ï-values are a favorable factor for long-term in vivo efficacy.(55,56)

    Binding Mode Studies

    Next, we sought to investigate the inhibition mode of CA28a with HsFPPS. We first investigated 6 (zoledronate), which is a validated DMAPP/GPP site competitive inhibitor (IC50 = 220 nM, Figure 8a). When 6 was preincubated with GPP + Mg2+ and HsFPPS for 30 min before the assay began, its IC50 increased considerably (to IC50 = 2.0 Î¼M); since 6 is a competitive inhibitor at this site, GPP + Mg2+ binding decreases its efficacy. However, when co-incubated with IPP, the IC50 of 6 was observed to be about the same or slightly smaller (173 nM vs 220 nM), since 6 does not bind to the IPP site.(57,58) With CA28a (Figure 8b), we find an IC50 of 370 nM when preincubated with only HsFPPS for 30 min. However, preincubation of CA28a with GPP + Mg2+ essentially completely abolished all inhibition activity of CA28a (red curve in Figure 6b, IC50 â« 50 Î¼M) due, we propose, to GPP + Mg2+ resulting in a partial closure of the protein structure which prevents CA28a binding. Preincubation with CA28a + GPP alone had essentially no effect, consistent with the fact that there are no GPP (or DMAPP) structures of FPPS in the absence of Mg2+, while preincubation of CA28a with IPP and HsFPPS did result in an increase in IC50 (to 6.3 Î¼M), suggesting that CA28a might bind near the IPP site.
    To help further clarify the inhibition mechanism, we measured MichaelisâMenten inhibition kinetics with CA28a, Figure 8c,d. Compound CA28a was found to be a noncompetitive inhibitor with respect to both GPP and IPP, and the Km values of GPP and IPP remained at 2.2 Î¼M and 4.4 Î¼M, respectively (overall fitting R2 values were 0.94 and 0.92). The striking affinity difference between preincubation with GPP + Mg2+ versus GPP indicates the importance of Mg2+ in blocking CA28aâs activity, and since Mg2+ is required for the conformational transition from the open to the partly closed state,(33) this suggests that the partly closed conformation prevents CA28a binding to HsFPPS. Taken together, the above results indicate that CA28a functions primarily by binding to the open state of HsFPPS, preventing substrate binding and pocket closure required for catalytic activity. We should also note here that since our compounds in many cases contain a nucleophilic receptor which can react with an electrophilic donor such as cysteine, they might also act as covalent inhibitors. We therefore performed time-dependent preincubation assays but found that IC50 values were not dependent on the length of preincubation (Table S2). Plus, preincubation of excess CA28a with HsFPPS overnight did not result in any adduct formation, as determined by LCâMS (Figure S4).

    Computational Docking, Mutagenesis and STD NMR

    In order to determine how our inhibitors might bind to HsFPPS, we used a combination of computational docking using Glide(59) together with site-directed mutagenesis and saturation transfer difference (STD) NMR. Since our kinetics studies indicated that CA28a bound to an open conformation, we used two open structures for docking: HsFPPS + two taxodiones (4P0X) and HsFPPS with the allosteric inhibitor 14(32) (5JV1).
    As for 4P0V (taxodione + zoledronate + 3 Mg2+) and 4P0W (arenarone + zoledronate + 3 Mg2+), it is difficult to dock CA28a into these two cocrystals since the structures are closed, so we did not attempt docking. We used structures with and without water molecules and, where appropriate, with or without sulfate ions. Four top ranked poses are shown in Figure 9.
    Features found in many but not all poses include a T-shaped ÏâÏ interaction between Phe-239 and the oxadiazole ring, and H-bond interactions between Asn-59 and the oxadiazole or ligand carbonyl groups. However, the orientations of CA28a were in many cases flipped, resulting in different ligandâprotein interactions as well as differences in solvent exposure. To try and clarify which interactions might be most important, we used site-directed mutagenesis. We made two mutants, N59A and F239A, in order to determine whether the H-bond or ÏâÏ stacking interactions were more important. As shown in Figure 10a,b, CA28a exhibited essentially the same IC50 against the N59A mutant HsFPPS as against wild type protein, but the IC50 against the F239A mutant HsFPPS was â¼500% larger than against wild type protein, Figure 10a,c. So the mutagenesis experiments indicate that an interaction between Phe-239 and CA28a is important for inhibition/binding while Asn-59 is not essential for binding. This result supported the docking pose in 4P0X (Figure 9a).
    Overlay of four poses shown in Figure 9 indicates that the pose in 4P0X (Figure 10d, green) is more buried than the other three poses, which are more exposed to water. We thus next carried out saturation difference (STD) NMR experiments in which (in brief) protein resonances are saturated, leading to decreased intensity of nearby bound ligand protons or, in a difference spectrum, large signals for ligand groups that are more buried/less solvent exposed, to further validate this pose. As can be seen in Figure 10e, there are six STD peaks, five of which are the methyl groups C16, C17, C18, C19, and C23. This result indicated the isopropyl group (C16,17), C18,19, and oxadiazole ring are more buried like the pose in 4P0X (Figure 10d, green), unlike poses such as that shown in 5JV1 (Figure 10d, cyan, magenta, and yellow), consistent with the pose shown in Figure 9a.
    Therefore, on the basis of the totality of the docking, mutagenesis, and STD results, we conclude that the docking pose shown in Figure 9a is a reasonable one. As shown for clarity in Figure S5, CA28a occupies the S2âS3 sites with its oxadiazole ring inserting deeply into the allosteric site, the benzoquinone partially occupying the IPP site S2 and the A ring colocating to the S3 site, the allosteric FPP site, although of course X-ray structures are needed to confirm this. Nevertheless, when taking all of the activity, kinetics, NMR, SPR, docking, and mutagenesis results together, we conclude that CA28a (and by inference, its analogs) inserts into the allosteric site of unliganded HsFPPS, preventing the binding of DMAPP/GPP and the subsequent conformational changes needed for catalysis.
    The catalytic mechanism of HsFPPS as well as its inhibition by 6 and CA28a is summarized in cartoon form in Figure 11. HsFPPS is initially expected to be ligand free, then DMAPP and (probably) 2 Mg2+ bind, Figure 11a,b. There are no X-ray structures of FPPS with DMAPP or GPP with 3 Mg2+ bound, but structures of an avian FPPS reveal binding of 2 Mg2+ and the structure is partially closed. Then, IPP and a third Mg2+ bind, forming the catalytically competent structure, Figure 11c. In the presence of CA28a, the surface pocket is occupied, Figure 11d, and the entrance for DMAPP and IPP is blocked. These open structures are very different from those found with bisphosphonate inhibitors such as zoledronate (6) where there are large numbers of X-ray structures that all contain the bisphosphonate with 3 Mg2+ and the structures are all largely closed, Figure 11e, with IPP binding then finally closing the structure, Figure 11f.

    Cell Growth Inhibition

    To investigate whether the compounds discussed above are active at the cellular level, we tested their ability to inhibit the growth of pancreatic cancer cells. As noted above, the activities of mutated Ras can be downregulated by HsFPPS inhibitors through prenylation blockade. PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2 are typical pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cell lines with elevated expression of a mutated Ras, KRAS, which plays as a major role in pancreatic cancer.(8,60) Statins have been reported to have anticancer effects in pancreatic cancer cell lines in vitro and in vivo,(61) and current evidence shows that statins act mainly by blockade of downstream small GTPase prenylation.(62â64) Direct inhibition of HsFPPS to block the prenylation of small GTPase is thus expected to inhibit pancreatic cancer cell growth. We chose to investigate two cell lines, PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2, to evaluate the potency of our inhibitors. By way of a control, we used the HsFPPS inhibitor zoledronate (6) which showed an EC50 of 16.1â24.2 Î¼M in PANC-1 cells, consistent with reported values.(65) It was slightly more potent in MIA PaCa-2 cells with an EC50 of 13.4 Î¼M, a dramatic decrease in its activity in cells when contrasted with its potency in HsFPPS inhibition (IC50 = 0.1â0.2 Î¼M), presumably due to poor cell permeability.
    As can be seen in Table 5, although most of the compounds tested are not as potent as 6 in HsFPPS enzyme inhibition, 21 out of 31 compounds displayed better activity than did 6 against PANC-1 cells, due most likely to improved cell penetration since clogP and clogD7.4 values are improved, Table 5. The most potent inhibitor in PANC-1 cells was CA15a (EC50 = 2.7 Î¼M), with an IC50 of 28.0 Î¼M toward HsFPPS. However, CA15a was also the most potent HsGGPPS inhibitor (IC50 = 5.5 Î¼M) and HsGGPPS inhibition can block pancreatic cancer cell growth through disruption of Rab-mediated activity.(66) We also see that most of the quinone-containing compounds (CA13, CA14, CA22, CA28a, and CA28c) have an EC50 of >40.0 Î¼M. Most had an IC50 below 1 Î¼M toward HsFPPS, so this efficacy loss may imply that most quinone derivatives react with compounds such as glutathione in the cellular environment before they bind to HsFPPS, thereby losing their activity.
    Table 5. Cellular Activities of Compounds toward Cancer Cell Linesa
    a

    ND, not determined.

    Given the very diverse range of compounds investigated (e.g., catechols, quinones, amines, carboxylates), it is unclear whether or not one would expect a good correlation between HsFPPS inhibition and cell activity since there could be compound metabolism as well as large differences in cellular uptake. We thus next investigated whether there were in fact correlations between enzyme inhibition and cell activity by simply plotting the corresponding IC50 and EC50 values, using for clarity a semilog scale since the enzyme inhibition results covered a larger range of values. We deleted inactives (defined as compounds with EC50 > 40 Î¼M, in cells) as well as that for CA15a, the HsGGPPS inhibitor.
    Results for PANC-1 cells are shown in Figure 12a from which it can be seen that there is a âVâ shaped overall curve. For the eight compounds on the right of the graph there is a very good correlation between HsFPPS inhibition and PANC-1 cell growth inhibition with a Pearson correlation coefficient R = 0.9. This supports the idea that these compounds target HsFPPS. The same trend is seen with the MIA PaCa-2 cell line although there are fewer points: both data sets are shown superimposed in Figure 12b from which it can be seen that in both cell lines there is a correlation between cell growth inhibition and HsFPPS inhibition for the less active HsFPPS inhibitors, indicating that HsFPPS is a likely target in both cell lines. For the more potent HsFPPS inhibitors (the compounds on the left in both graphs in Figure 12), there appears to be an inverse correlation with the PANC-1 cell line, but this is less obvious when data from both cell lines are considered, Figure 12b. We found no correlations between EC50 with clogP or clogD7.4, Figure S6. So the results shown above support an HsFPPS target for the nine compounds that are, paradoxically, the less active HsFPPS inhibitors. This raises the question as to the targets of the more potent HsFPPS inhibitors that have good activity in cells, so we next investigated compound CA5d which is one of the most active species in the cluster of compounds on the left of Figure 12a,b, as well as being a potent HsFPPS inhibitor. We did not choose CA18 and CA15a which displayed more potent activities toward PANC-1 cells compared with CA5d as our tool compounds for verifying their mechanisms of action since they both got weak potencies toward HsFPPS (7.80 Î¼M and 28.0 Î¼M, respectively) and CA15a is also the most potent HsGGPPS inhibitor among these derivatives, raising concerns about off-targets effect.

    Mechanism of Action of CA5d: Induction of Apoptosis and Downregulation of Ras Prenylation

    To pinpoint the target of CA5d in cells, we investigated whether it blocked protein prenylation and induced apoptosis that could be blocked by adding ârescue agentsâ, farnesol (FOH) and/or geranylgeraniol (GGOH), since these can be converted in cells by kinases to FPP or GGPP.(67) PANC-1 cells were treated with PBS (phosphate buffered saline, control), 6 (positive control, 10 Î¼M), or CA5d (10, 20, 40 Î¼M) for 48 h. Apoptosis was detected by staining of annexin V and propidium iodide (PI) and showed a dose-dependent correlation between apoptosis rate and CA5d exposure, Figure 13. CA5d had a statistically significant effect on apoptosis as compared to the control when its concentration was >10 Î¼M. Both 6 and CA5d induced primarily early but not late stage apoptosis when the concentration was low (10 Î¼M), and CA5d induced both early and late stage apoptosis when its concentration was high (20, 40 Î¼M, Figure 13c,d).
    To determine whether apoptosis was induced by HsFPPS inhibition, we performed cell growth inhibition rescue experiments (Figure 14) since HsFPPS inhibition will cause both FPP and GGPP starvation in cells, leading to prenylation blockade of downstream proteins including Ras, Rab, Rho, and Rac. Figure 14a shows that the effects of 6 and CA5d on apoptosis can be largely rescued by addition of GGOH and FOH (10 Î¼M), indicating that CA5d acts in the same manner as does 6, by inhibiting HsFPPS. GGOH and FOH alone did not show any effects on cell apoptosis. We also note that the effect of CA5d (at 20 Î¼M) on apoptosis is not fully rescued by GGOH + FOH since there was still a 2.8% higher apoptosis rate as compared to the 6 control group. So although most of the apoptosis effects were rescued, it does appear that CA5d has additional off-target (non-HsFPPS) activity or nonspecific cytotoxicity (e.g., ROS) in PANC-1 cells (as do the cluster of compounds to the left of the graphs).
    Next, we determined the effects of CA5d on protein prenylation by measuring the amount of membrane Ras by Western blot after a 24 h treatment with CA5d. As briefly noted above, Ras can be regulated by HsFPPS activity via its prenylation with FPP, so HsFPPS inhibition in cells should lead to a decrease in membrane Ras. Figure 14b shows a dose-dependent decrease of membrane Ras when cells are treated with increasing concentrations of CA5d, while the amount of total Ras (membrane Ras plus cytoplasmic Ras) remained unchanged. These results indicate that CA5d affects the relocalization of cytoplasmic Ras via HsFPPS inhibition, leading to the accumulation of cytoplasm Ras and a decrease of membrane Ras. Membrane Ras is indispensable for Ras signaling and it is well-known that Ras blockade can result in later apoptosis in cancer cells.(7,60,68,69) Taking all these results into consideration, we propose the mechanism of action of CA5d illustrated in Figure 14c: HsFPPS inhibition of CA5d leads to a decrease in FPP and GGPP, which results in the decline of membrane Ras. Reduction of membrane Ras finally causes PANC-1 cell apoptosis.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates, N-BPs, have clear antiosteoporosis benefits, and promising bone-related anticancer effects have been reported in several clinical results.(17â23) However, whether they have anticancer activity in soft tissues is controversial,(70â72) and it is generally thought that the development of HsFPPS inhibitors with better cell permeability is desirable. Here, we report the discovery and development of a series of non-bisphosphonate HsFPPS inhibitors based on a natural product hit, carnosic acid (CA). CA had an IC50 of 20 Î¼M toward HsFPPS, a good start for further optimization, leading to derivatives such as CA16b, CA25e, and CA28b which had nearly equal potency to that of zoledronate (6). HsFPPS inhibitors with IC50 below 1 Î¼M showed weak or no activity toward HsGGPPS. Results from [14C]-IPP radioactivity assays, catalase-addition assays, and Triton X-100 assays excluded the possibility of PAINS-interference, and WaterLOGSY NMR and SPR experiments confirmed the physical binding of our compounds to HsFPPS. The SPR results also indicated slow dissociation kinetics of CA1, CA13, and CA28a, suggesting potential long-lasting effects in vivo.
    Binding modes were evaluated via enzyme kinetics and preincubation assays with GPP/GPP+Mg2+/IPP with CA28a exhibiting noncompetitive inhibition with respect to GPP and IPP. When combined with the results of docking studies, we propose that CA28a is an allosteric inhibitor that binds to HsFPPS in its open conformation, as found with known HsFPPS allosteric site inhibitors. Since this series of inhibitors form stable complexes with similar on rates but slow and variable off-rates, this may indicate that further optimization should focus on reducing the dissociation rate. The cellular activities of our compounds toward PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2 cells were also evaluated. As expected, most inhibitors were more potent than 6 in cells even though they had weaker enzyme inhibition activities. Also notable was the observation that CA15a inhibited both HsFPPS and HsGGPPS and had potent activity against two pancreatic cancer cell lines, so the development of such dual inhibitors appears to be of interest. We also found evidence, using rescue experiments for HsFPPS inhibition in cells, leading to decreased Ras prenylation and subsequent apoptosis. It is also noteworthy that such compounds carrying quinone or catechol moieties must be carefully evaluated because of their likely PANIS properties and potential nonspecific cytotoxicities.
    In summary, the natural-product-derived HsFPPS inhibitors discussed here were based on previous observations that related diterpenoids were HsFPPS inhibitors, as well as the observation that CA and carnosol, components of rosemary and sage, have diverse biological activities. The compounds we synthesized eliminated the highly charged bisphosphonate or carboxylic acid fragments of traditional HsFPPS inhibitors and were found to be active in pancreatic cancer cell killing where they acted by targeting HsFPPS. However, there are still many topics to explore including the exact binding mode of our compounds with HsFPPS, more optimization to enhance cellular activities, and evaluation of effects in animal models; work in all three areas is currently underway.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry Synthesis and Characterization

    All chemicals (except for carnosic acid) and solvents were of reagent grade. Carnosic acid was technical grade and was purified via silica gel column chromatography (200â300 mesh, Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd.). Reactions were monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). 1H and 13C spectra were recorded on a Bruker ADVANCE III 400 MHz spectrometer. Solvent residues or tetramethylsilane (TMS) was used as internal references. 1H spectra are reported as chemical shifts (Î´ ppm), peak multiplicity (s, d, t, q, b, m), and coupling constants (J, Hz). 13C spectra are reported as chemical shifts (Î´, ppm). High-resolution mass spectrometric (HRMS) analyses were conducted on a Waters mass spectrometer using positive ion or negative ion mode. The purities of the key final compounds were determined to be â¥95% by NMR and HPLC.

    Synthesis of Final Compounds. Procedure a1

    Reactant catechol (1.0 equiv) and 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanobenzoquinone (DDQ, 1.1 equiv) were dissolved in 1,4-dioxane and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The mixture was then filtered with diatomite, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography using PE/EA.

    Procedure a2

    Reactant catechol (1.0 equiv) and Ag2O (1.1 equiv) were dissolved in 1,4-dioxane and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The mixture was then filtered with diatomite, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography using PE/EA.

    Procedure b

    CA3 (1.0 equiv) was dissolved in dry DCM and (CO)2Cl2 (excessive amount), and a catalytic amount of dry DMF was then slowly added to the mixture which was then allowed to react at room temperature overnight under an Ar atmosphere. The mixture was then concentrated in vacuo, and the corresponding acyl chlorides residues were used in the next step without further purification. The acyl chlorides were dissolved in dry DCM at 0 Â°C, then the corresponding amines R1NH2 (1.5â2.0 equiv, except for CA4l) and DMAP (1.5â2.0 equiv) were added. The mixtures were then slowly warmed to room temperature or 35 Â°C, stirred for 2 h, washed with 2 N HCl and saturated brine, extracted with DCM, and concentrated in vacuo to give the residues to be purified by silica gel column chromatography using PE/EA to yield CA4aâk.

    Procedure c1

    Acetyl-protected catechol CA4aâl (1.0 equiv) was dissolved in toluene. To this solution, p-TSAÂ·H2O (4.0â6.0 equiv) was added under an Ar atmosphere. The mixtures were then heated to 80 Â°C until reaction completion. They were then washed with saturated NaHCO3, extracted with EA, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography to obtain the corresponding compounds.

    Procedure c2

    Acetyl-protected catechol CA4aâl (1.0 equiv) was dissolved in dry THF. To this solution, LiAlH4 (5.0 equiv) was slowly added at 0 Â°C. The stirred mixture was then allowed to slowly warm to room temperature. On reaction completion, excess LiAlH4 was quenched with saturated NH4Cl, the mixture was washed twice with brine, extracted with EA, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography to obtain the corresponding compounds.

    Procedure c3

    Acetyl-protected catechol (1.0 equiv) and NaHCO3 (13.7 equiv) were added to MeOH/H2O (4:1) and stirred at 65 Â°C overnight. The mixture was then washed with 2 N HCl, extracted with EA, dried with anhydrous MgSO4, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography.

    Procedure d

    Acetyl-protected catechol (1.0 equiv) and CrO3 (2.0 equiv) were dissolved in AcOH at room temperature and stirred for 12 h, after which the mixture was concentrated in vacuo, redissolved in EA/DCM, washed with saturated NaHCO3, extracted with EA, and purified by silica gel column chromatography.

    Procedure e

    CA2 (1.0 equiv) and corresponding nucleophilic reagent R4X2H (1.1 equiv) were dissolved in MeOH or EtOH at 0 Â°C (when X2 = S) or room temperature (when X2 = O) and were stirred until reaction completion. Then, the mixture was concentrated in vacuo and the product purified by silica gel column chromatography.

    Procedure f1

    CA4i,j (1.0 equiv) was added into an excess amount of POCl3 which served as both reactant and solvent. The mixture was then stirred at 80 Â°C for 1â5 h until reaction completion. Then, the mixture was washed with saturated NaHCO3 and brine, dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and purified by silica gel column chromatography. CA25a,b were obtained in 31â41% yield.

    Procedure f2

    CA4k (1.0 equiv) was dissolved in DCM/CH3CN (1:1). 4-Toluenesulfonyl chloride (p-TsCl, 3.0 equiv) and diisopropylethylamine (DIEA, 5.0 equiv) were then added, and the mixture was allowed to react at 65 Â°C until the reaction completed. Then, the mixture was washed with saturated NH4Cl and brine, dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and purified by silica gel column chromatography.

    Procedure g

    Carboxylic acid R5COOH (1.5 equiv), hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyluronium (HATU, 1.5 equiv), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIEA, 2.0 equiv) were dissolved and stirred in DCM at room temperature for 30 min. After the solution became clear, CA4h (1.0 equiv) was added into the mixture which was then stirred overnight until the reaction completed. Then, the mixture was washed with brine, extracted with EA, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography to form compounds CA23aâc.

    Methyl (4aR,10aS)-5,6-Dihydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthrene-4a(2H)-carboxylate (CA1)

    Carnosic acid (CA, 3.32 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in 90 mL of toluene/MeOH (5:1) at 0 Â°C. Trimethylsilyldiazomethane (TMSCHN2, 10 mL, 20 mmol) was then slowly added to the mixture. After reaction completion indicated by TLC, solvent was removed in vacuo and the product washed with brine, extracted with EA, dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and purified by silica gel column chromatography using PE/EA. CA1 was obtained in 90% yield (3.1 g). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 7.48 (s, 1H), 6.55 (s, 1H), 5.79 (s, 1H), 3.68 (s, 3H), 3.33â3.29 (m, 1H), 3.21 (hept, 1H), 2.83â2.80 (m, 2H), 2.35â2.24 (m, 1H), 1.89â1.85 (m, 1H), 1.71â1.55 (m, 3H), 1.48â1.45 (m, 1H), 1.35â1.27 (m, 2H), 1.25 (d, J = 4.9 Hz, 3H), 1.23 (d, J = 4.4 Hz, 3H), 1.00 (s, 3H), 0.80 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 179.0, 142.2, 141.8, 133.5, 128.6, 122.1, 119.3, 54.1, 52.3, 49.2, 42.2, 35.1, 34.5, 32.8, 31.8, 27.3, 22.6, 22.3, 21.9, 20.5, 19.4. HRMS m/z calcd for C21H29O4 (M â H)â, 345.2066; found, 345.2056.

    Methyl (4aR,10aS)-5-Hydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-6-oxo-1,3,4,6,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthrene-4a(2H)-carboxylate (CA2)

    Procedure a1/a2 was used for the synthesis of CA2, using CA1 (3.16 g, 9.1 mmol) and DDQ (2.2 g, 9.7 mmol) or Ag2O (2.2 g, 9.7 mmol). CA2 was provided in 66% yield (2.05 g, procedure a1). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 7.62 (s, 1H), 6.93 (dd, J = 6.8, 3.1 Hz, 1H), 6.85 (s, 1H), 3.72 (dt, J = 13.5, 4.0 Hz, 1H), 3.62 (s, 3H), 3.07 (h, J = 6.7 Hz, 1H), 2.95 (ddd, J = 20.7, 12.3, 3.1 Hz, 1H), 2.63 (ddd, J = 20.6, 6.8, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 1.98 (qt, J = 13.9, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 1.79 (dd, J = 12.3, 4.4 Hz, 1H), 1.62 (dt, J = 14.4, 3.6 Hz, 1H), 1.51â1.43 (m, 1H), 1.38â1.19 (m, 2H), 1.14 (dd, J = 6.9, 5.0 Hz, 6H), 0.95 (s, 3H), 0.80 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 181.0, 173.6, 150.8, 146.3, 140.6, 137.2, 130.9, 118.6, 51.8, 51.0, 47.2, 41.9, 34.1, 33.3, 32.1, 26.9, 26.8, 21.9, 21.5, 20.1, 20.0. HRMS m/z calcd for C21H29O4 (M + H)+, 345.2066; found, 345.2051.

    (4aR,10aS)-5,6-Diacetoxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthrene-4a(2H)-carboxylic Acid (CA3)

    Compound CA (8 g, 24.1 mmol) was dissolved in dichloromethane (DCM, 100 mL). Acetic anhydride (11.4 mL, 120.6 mmol) and 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP, 3.5 g, 28.6 mmol) were added to the solution at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, washed with 2 N HCl and then saturated brine, extracted with DCM, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. The remaining filtrate was then concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography using petroleum ether (PE)/ethyl acetate (EA) to give CA3 (9.9 g, 23.9 mmol, 99%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 10.45 (br, 1H), 6.95 (s, 1H), 3.22 (d, J = 13.3 Hz, 1H), 2.98â2.79 (m, 3H), 2.40â2.27 (m, 1H), 2.26 (s, 3H), 2.24 (s, 3H), 2.16â2.09 (m, 1H), 1.88â1.79 (m, 1H), 1.57â1.41 (m, 3H), 1.33â1.22 (m, 2H), 1.21 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 3H), 1.14 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 3H), 0.96 (s, 3H), 0.86 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 180.7, 168.8, 168.2, 141.5, 140.0, 138.8, 136.9, 132.2, 125.3, 54.0, 47.7, 41.2, 34.6, 34.1, 32.6, 32.1, 27.5, 23.1, 22.8, 20.6, 20.5, 20.2, 19.9, 18.2.

    (4bR,8aS)-4b-(2-Acetylhydrazine-1-carbonyl)-2-isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-4b,5,6,7,8,8a,9,10-octahydrophenanthrene-3,4-diyl Diacetate (CA4i)

    Compound CA3 (6.06 g, 14.5 mmol) was dissolved in dry DCM (100 mL). Oxalyl chloride (48.5 mL) was slowly added into the solution, then dry dimethylformamide (DMF, 0.66 mL) was added dropwise. The final mixture was allowed to react at room temperature overnight under an Ar atmosphere. After completion, the mixture was concentrated in vacuo and the acyl chloride product was directly used in the next step without further purification. The acyl chloride was dissolved in dry DCM (100 mL), and acethydrazide (2.1 g, 28.4 mmol) and DMAP (3.5 g, 28.6 mmol) were added at 0 Â°C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 35 Â°C for 2 h, washed with 2 N HCl and brine, extracted with DCM, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and then concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography using PE/EA to give CA4i (5.06 g, 12.1 mmol, 83.5%) in two steps. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 8.40 (br, 1H), 7.65 (s, 1H), 6.94 (s, 1H), 3.16â3.13 (m, 1H), 2.98â2.85 (m, 2H), 2.82 (hepta, 1H), 2.22 (s, 3H), 2.18 (s, 3H), 2.22â2.18 (m, 1H), 2.00â1.90 (m, 1H), 1.84 (s, 3H), 1.54 (m, 3H), 1.23â1.20 (m, 2H), 1.17 (d, 3H), 1.11 (d, 3H), 0.93 (s, 3H), 0.80 (s, 3H), 0.85â0.70 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 171.7, 168.3, 168.2, 166.8, 141.2, 140.4, 138.8, 135.9, 132.7, 125.3, 52.4, 47.2, 39.9, 34.0, 33.5, 32.1, 31.2, 27.2, 22.7, 22.6, 20.4, 20.3, 20.3, 20.2, 19.7, 18.6.

    (4aR,10aS)-Nâ²-(4-Bromobenzoyl)-5,6-dihydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthrene-4a(2H)-carbohydrazide (CA5k)

    tert-Butyl ((S)-1-(2-((4aR,10aS)-5,6-Dihydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,2,3,4,4a,9,10,10a-octahydrophenanthrene-4a-carbonyl)hydrazinyl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl)carbamate (CA5l)

    CA5l was synthesized from CA4l by using procedure c2.CA4l was the condensation product of CA4h and N-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-l-alanine. N-(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)-l-alanine (1.1 g, 5.76 mmol), hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyluranium (HATU, 2.1 g, 5.76 mmol), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIEA, 1.3 mL, 7.68 mmol) were dissolved in DCM (20 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. After the solution became clear, CA4h (1.66 g, 3.84 mmol) was added and the mixture stirred overnight until the reaction completed. Then, the mixture was washed with brine, extracted with EA, concentrated in vacuo, and purified by silica gel column chromatography. CA4l (1.59 g) was obtained in 69% yield. CA4l (0.1 g, 0.17 mmol) was then deprotected by using procedure c2 and CA5l was obtained in 68% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 8.95 (s, 1H), 7.88 (br, 1H), 7.53 (br, 1H), 6.60 (s, 1H), 6.27 (s, 1H), 5.53 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 4.23â4.13 (m, 1H), 3.51 (d, J = 14.8 Hz, 1H), 3.16 (hept, J = 6.9 Hz, 1H), 2.82 (m, 2H), 2.22 (t, J = 9.6 Hz, 1H), 2.12â2.01 (m, 1H), 1.85 (d, J = 12.9 Hz, 1H), 1.65â1.50 (m, 4H), 1.41 (s, 9H), 1.38â1.26 (m, 2H), 1.21â1.19 (m, 2H), 1.19â1.13 (m, 6H), 0.97 (s, 3H), 0.84 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 175.5, 173.6, 156.0, 144.3, 141.2, 133.9, 130.0, 128.4, 121.0, 80.9, 54.5, 48.1, 41.2, 34.4, 34.0, 32.7, 31.7, 29.8, 28.5, 28.4, 27.3, 27.0, 22.8, 22.3, 21.1, 20.3, 19.3, 17.6.

    Methyl (4aR,10aS)-5-((tert-Butyldimethylsilyl)oxy)-6-hydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthrene-4a(2H)-carboxylate (CA8a)

    CA1 (0.1 g, 0.29 mmol) was dissolved in DCM (5 mL).     (4aR,11aS)-7-Hydroxy-8-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,10,11,11a-hexahydro-2H,5H-phenanthro[4,4b-bc]furan-5-one (CA17)

    CA (5 g, 15 mmol) and dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC, 4 g, 15.5 mmol) were stirred in 100 mL of DCM at room temperature. DMAP (0.2 g, 1.5 mmol) was then added into the mixture and allowed to react until completion. After that, the mixture was filtered and concentrated in vacuo and purified by silica gel column chromatography.     (4bR,8aS)-4b-(Hydroxymethyl)-2-isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-4b,5,6,7,8,8a,9,10-octahydrophenanthrene-3,4-diol (CA18)

    CA18 was synthesized from CA in two steps: CA was first subjected to methylation leading to CA1, which was then reduced by LiAlH4 to afford CA18. LiAlH4 (32.4 mg) was dissolved in dry THF, and CA1 (0.1 g, 0.29 mmol) dissolved in dry THF (3 mL) was then slowly added to the mixture at 0 Â°C. After reaction completion (as indicated by TLC), the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 1.0â3.0 using 2 N HCl. Then, the mixture was washed with brine, dried with MgSO4, concentrated, and purified by silica gel column chromatography. CA18 (40.1 g) was afforded in 43% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 8.70 (s, 1H), 6.54 (s, 1H), 5.97 (s, 1H), 4.48 (d, J = 9.7 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (d, J = 9.7 Hz, 1H), 3.29â3.14 (m, 2H), 2.95â2.80 (m, 2H), 2.33 (s, 1H), 1.83â1.71 (m, 1H), 1.75â1.57 (m, 2H), 1.61â1.47 (m, 1H), 1.44 (dd, J = 7.4, 5.7 Hz, 2H), 1.35â1.26 (m, 2H), 1.23 (dd, J = 7.0, 5.6 Hz, 6H), 0.98 (s, 3H), 0.89 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 142.3, 142.2, 132.6, 130.2, 127.7, 119.0, 67.4, 52.8, 44.1, 41.2, 34.0, 33.7, 32.1, 31.4, 27.3, 22.9, 22.7, 22.4, 19.1, 19.0.     (4bR,8aS)-2-Isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-4b-(5-methyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)-4b,5,6,7,8,8a,9,10-octahydrophenanthrene-3,4-diyl Diacetate (CA24a)

    tert-Butyl ((S)-1-(5-((4aR,10aS)-5,6-dihydroxy-7-isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9,10,10a-hexahydrophenanthren-4a(2H)-yl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)ethyl)carbamate (CA25d)

    (4bR)-2-Isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-4b-(5-methyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)-5,6,7,8,8a,9-hexahydrophenanthrene-3,4,10(4bH)-trione (CA28a)

    Compound CA27a (1.7 g, 4.4 mmol) and 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanobenzoquinone (DDQ, 1.13 g, 4.92 mmol) were dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (50 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 30 min.     tert-Butyl ((S)-1-(5-((4aR,10aS)-7-Isopropyl-1,1-dimethyl-5,6,9-trioxo-1,3,4,5,6,9,10,10a-octahydrophenanthren-4a(2H)-yl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)ethyl)carbamate (CA28b)

    (4bR,8aS)-4b-(5-Acetyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)-2-isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-5,6,7,8,8a,9-hexahydrophenanthrene-3,4,10(4bH)-trione (CA28c)

    (4bR,8aS)-4b-(5-(4-Bromophenyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)-2-isopropyl-8,8-dimethyl-5,6,7,8,8a,9-hexahydrophenanthrene-3,4,10(4bH)-trione (CA28d)

    Enzymatic Activity Assays

    HsFPPS and HsGGPPS activities were determined via PPi release using a continuous spectrophotometric assay for phosphate releasing enzymes,(42) as described previously.(27,73)HsFPPS WT, HsFPPS N59A, or HsFPPS F239A was preincubated with compounds at room temperature for 30 min before the addition of GPP and IPP. The final reaction system contained 200 Î¼L of reaction mixture. The reaction buffer contained 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) and 2 mM MgCl2. In some cases, 50 Î¼g/mL catalase or 0.01% Triton X-100 was added, as discussed above. Kinetics assays were carried out in a similar manner except that the GPP and IPP concentrations were varied. IC50 values were calculated by fitting the inhibition data to the doseâresponse curves in Prism 7. For the [14C]-IPP radioactivity assay, the protocol was as described in the literature.(58)

    WaterLOGSY

    This experiment was performed according to the method reported in literature.(26)HsFPPS concentration was 10 Î¼M, and CA28a/CA5d was 200/400 Î¼M. Tris buffer (25 mM Tris, pH 7.5) without DTT was used for this experiment.

    Saturation Transfer Difference (STD) NMR

    STD was performed according to the method reported in literature.(75) Sample for STD was prepared with 400 Î¼M CA28a in 5% DMSO-d6, 10 Î¼M HsFPPS in Hepes buffer (1.5%), and 10% D2O in PBS (pH 7.4).

    Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR)

    SPR was performed at 25 Â°C on a Reichert 4SPR using a carboxymethyl dextran sensor chip. Phosphate buffered saline containing 0.05% Tween-20 (PBST) and 5% DMSO were used as running buffer. The amount of HsFPPS captured was about 5000 Î¼RIU (refractive index unit). Flow rate was 25 Î¼L/min. CA1 and CA28a were assayed at 40â2.5 Î¼M with 2-fold dilution. CA5l and CA13 were assayed at 50, 37.5, 25, 18.75, and 12.5 Î¼M.

    Computational Methods

    Protein structures were prepared by using the Protein Preparation Wizard(74) in Schrodinger software by adding hydrogens, while waters beyond 5 Ã from inhibitor ligands groups were deleted. PROPKA was used to assign H-bonds present at pH 7.0. Then, restrained minimization was performed and the prepared proteins were used for subsequent protein alignments, grid generation, and docking.
    Grids of 4P0X and 5JV1 (with/without sulfate ions and waters) were generated using default settings. Compound CA28a was prepared for docking by using LigPrep. Ionization states of CA28a were generated between pH 5.0 and pH 9.0 by Epik.(76) Finally, the prepared CA28a and protein structures were docked by using the standard precision method in Glide and docking poses were visualized, analyzed using Maestro 11.9 and Pymol 2.(77)

    Cellular Activity Evaluation

    Cell growth inhibition was determined by using an MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay. PANC-1 and MIA PaCa-2 cells were seeded at 4 Ã 103 cells per well in a 96-well flat bottomed plate and allowed to adhere at 37 Â°C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere overnight before addition of drugs. 200 Î¼L of DMEM (Dulbeccoâs modified Eagle medium) was used in each well. The next day, inhibitor-free medium was replaced by inhibitor-containing DMEM. There were three duplicates for each inhibitor concentration. Plates were then incubated at 37 Â°C and 5% CO2 atmosphere for 72 h. After incubation, 20 Î¼L of MTT (5 mg/mL, dissolved in PBS) was added to each well and the plates were incubated for a further 4 h period. Finally, the medium was removed and the formed formazan was dissolved in 150 Î¼L of DMSO per well. Cell densities were measured at 490 nm. Doseâresponse curves and EC50 values were fitted by using Prism 7.

    Apoptosis Assay

    The apoptosis rates of PANC-1 cells were measured by using an annexin V-FITC/PI apoptosis detection kit (CWBIO). Briefly, 5 Ã 104 PANC-1 cells per well were incubated in a 12-well plate and allowed to grow in 1 mL of DMEM per well at 37 Â°C and 5% CO2 atmosphere overnight before compound treatment. After incubation, an additional 1 mL of DMEM containing the inhibitor was added to each well. Each concentration contained three duplicates. The following cell sample treatments were carried out according to the kit protocol. Briefly, after a 48 h incubation, cells were collected, resuspended twice in cold PBS, and then resuspended by using the binding buffer in the kit. Annexin V/FITC and PI were then added and incubated in the dark at room temperature for 15 min. Finally, flow cytometry was utilized to analyze the apoptosis rate of PANC-1 cells using FlowJo (FLOWJO LLC) for data processing.

    Rescue Experiments

    Rescue experiments were carried out by measuring the effects of various treatments (FOH and/or GGOH) on apoptosis rates, basically as described above. Briefly, after incubation overnight in a 12-well plate, cells were treated with rescue compounds for 48 h, followed by flow cytometry analysis. All experiments were performed using three duplicates.

    Western Blot Analysis of Membrane Ras

    Subcellular extractions of PANC-1 cell proteins and subsequent Western blots were used to measure the amount of membrane Ras and total Ras. PANC-1 cells were seeded into a 150 mm dish and were allowed to proliferate to about (2.0â5.0) Ã 107 cells/dish. After treatment with compounds for 24 h, cells were gently collected using a cell scraper and washed three times with cold PBS. Subsequent membrane protein extractions were conducted basically according to the protocol provided with the membrane and cytosol protein extraction kit (Beyotime). Cells were collected by centrifugation and suspended in 1 mL of extraction reagent A (containing freshly added phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, PMSF) in the kit. After cooling in an ice bath for 10â15 min, cells were subjected to three freeze/thaw cycles (between liquid nitrogen and room temperature), followed by centrifugation at 700g for 10 min at 4 Â°C. The supernatants were then collected and centrifuged at 14â¯000g for 30 min (again at 4 Â°C) to remove membrane fragments, and the supernatants were collected for cytosolic protein analysis. The cell membrane fragments were then treated with 200 Î¼L of extraction reagent B in the kit and vortexed for 5 s, then cooled in an ice bath for 5â10 min. The vortexing and ice-bath treatment was repeated two more times. After centrifugation at 14â¯000g for 15 min at 4 Â°C, the supernatant was collected as the membrane protein fraction. The cytosolic and membrane protein fractions were combined as the whole protein sample for Western blot analysis. Protein concentrations were determined by using a BCA (bicinchoninic acid assay) protein assay kit (CWBIO).
    42 Î¼g of membrane proteins and 80 Î¼g of whole proteins were used as Western blot samples. Membrane and whole proteins were separated by electrophoresis at 90 V, 25 min and then 130 V, 60 min. After that, protein transfer to a PVDF (polyvinylidene difluoride) membrane was conducted in an ice bath at 300 mA for 70 min. Subsequent blocking was performed in 5% nonfat dried milk (in PBS) at 4 Â°C, overnight. Rabbit anti-Ras antibody (abcam, EP1125Y), rabbit anti-sodium potassium ATPase antibody (abcam, EP1845Y), and mouse anti-Î² tubulin antibody (Byotime) were used at room temperature for 2 h in primary antibody incubation. After washing with PBST (0.05% Tween 20) five times for 5 min each, membranes were incubated with the corresponding secondary antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (mouse IgG for Î² tubulin, rabbit IgG was for the others; Byotime) at room temperature for 2 h. The same washing protocol was performed after secondary antibody incubation. The immunoblot bands were detected by using ECL (enhanced chemiluminescence) substrate (BeyoECL Plus) and then visualized in a Tanon gel imaging system.

    Protein Expression and Purification

    Clones encoding HsFPPS WT, HsFPPS N59A, HsFPPS F239A, or HsGGPPS residues as N-terminally His6-tagged fusion proteins with a TEV protease cleavage site were expressed in E. coli BL21(DE3). Cells were lysed by using an ultrasonic cell disruptor, and the proteins were purified by nickel affinity column chromatography (GE). The histidine tag was removed by incubation with TEV protease, and gel filtration chromatography was performed with a Superdex 200 column (GE). The purified enzymes were dialyzed against 10 mM HEPES/Tris buffer (pH 7.5) containing 500 mM NaCl and stored at â80 Â°C before use.
